instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD1: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD1? PP2V5_NAND_SSD1 is a power rail that powers the soldered on SSDs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board tries to startup but <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> gets hot and board turns off.

This board had a full short on <CAPACITOR>C9589</CAPACITOR> removed it and installed a new <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>, but that the new chip got fried too after I powered on the MacBook after that <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> is measuring 0.060 in diode mode, I removed the <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> checked it and its now shorted-fried.

I then checked each pad for <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> on the board and found no shorts, <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> measured 0.340 in diode mode after removing <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>, I also removed <CAPACITOR>C9586</CAPACITOR>/88/89/93 as they were a little rusted, and saw that the coil L9580 looks a little rusty, I do not have same coil from other board, schematics tell me that it is 1UH-20%-3.8A-0.035OHM out of those numbers what is the important one so I can find a coil that works is it 1UH-20% or 3.8A or 0.0350HM I assume the later one.

Anyway with all that I put a new <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> (second one) and same thing, it gets hot and becomes shorted after trying to power the MacBook, <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> gets shorted, I remove <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> and short is gone.

I have spent some time with this board now, very frustrating...

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Did you inspect J8500 for liquid sign?
Look at its pins 1 & 43 first.
I cannot understand how can you burn two chips.
If you find burnt chip, think first WHY; before applying power to the board with replaced chip!

And we talked many times about analog mux, named <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> in all recent boards...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Will try as suggested, can you please help me here: I do not have same coil from other board, schematics tell me that it is 1UH-20%-3.8A-0.035OHM out of those numbers what is the important one so I can find a coil that works is it 1UH-20% or 3.8A or 0.0350HM I assume the later one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
That code means the coil impedance is 1uH (microhenry) with 35 miliohm as internal resistance, designed for 3.8A as nominal current.
You should choose one coil with closest value possible for all these parameters.
The impedance is the most important property of a coil, but not always sufficient to work properly.
The design of a buck-converter will consider all these parameters...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks for the great explanation on inductors, I will make note of it.

J8500 is perfect, diode on pin 1 is 0.443 and pin 43 1.234 not shorts wither on all other pins, surrounding area looks clean too.

When you get frustrated and desperate you make stupid decisions, that's how I burned 2 new chips...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings between all data lines of <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>; w/ and w/o LCD connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So sorry, this whole time I mean <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>... I will start a new thread...
